subj-group.subject: Topics in Quality, Safety, Leadership, and Professionalism

title-group.article-title: Should Readmission Within 30 Days After Discharge of Children Hospitalized for a Neurologic Disorder Be Considered a Quality Assurance Failure?

article-meta.aff: 1Quality Improvement Team, Department of Neurology, Boston Children’s Hospital

author-notes.corresp: Alan Leviton, MD, Children's Hospital Boston, 300 Longwood Avenue, Boston MA 02115-5724. Email: alan.leviton@childrens.harvard.edu

abstract.p: The Affordable Care Act penalizes hospitals with high readmission rates. Children’s hospitals are not yet among these hospitals, although that is likely to change. Because chronic neurologic conditions represent a sizable proportion of all children’s hospitals costs, and because some/many of the readmissions might not be easily prevented, children’s hospitals and neurologists who care for children might be inappropriately penalized for some readmissions. We encourage more study to identify the correlates of readmission of children who have a neurologic disorder.

body.p: The US Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act's Hospital Readmission Reduction Program now penalizes hospitals for high readmission rates.1 Children’s hospitals are not yet among the institutions whose readmission rates are being scrutinized as part of implementing this readmission-reduction program.

The larger the number of patients who are unexpectedly readmitted to a hospital after a previous hospital stay, the less favorably a hospital is judged in delivering quality care.2 This is reasonable when readmission might be a legitimate indicator of suboptimal care. For example, an unplanned readmission for a surgical wound infection can reflect a sterility breach. But what if an unplanned readmission to the neurology service is unlikely to indicate a lapse in high-quality care? We believe that until we have a better understanding of what we do that increases the risk of readmission within a defined time interval, readmission of a patient to a pediatric neurology inpatient service should not be viewed as an indicator of suboptimal care.

The United States Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality uses the term “unnecessary readmission,” but it does not offer guidance about how to distinguish unnecessary from necessary readmissions.3 Consider that you have been given the undesirable task of reviewing the charts of all pediatric neurology readmissions that occurred within 30 days of discharge. You have to decide if each early readmission was unnecessary—not avoidable, but unnecessary. You are expected to decide to what extent physician, nurse, and hospital administration policies and decisions contributed to a child’s readmission.
How would you go about doing this? First, you would want to study the literature that has identified correlates of early readmission. So let us see what is known.

The overall readmission rate at acute pediatric care hospitals in the United States is approximately 6%.4 Fully 59% of readmissions reported in 34 studies published between 1966 and 2010 were deemed avoidable when administrative databases were used to assess preventability, whereas only 12% were deemed preventable in studies based on clinical data.5 Although the rate of readmissions varied substantially among 11 teaching and community hospitals in the province of Ontario, Canada, between 2002 and 2006, the proportion deemed preventable did not.6 Although the health care system in Ontario, Canada, differs from that of the health care system in the United States, the variability in readmission affirms how difficult it is to appreciably reduce readmission rates.

sec.title: Who Is at Risk?
sec.p: Unplanned hospital readmissions might reflect little more than the instability and severity of a child’s underlying disease. For example, children who have chronic disorders characterized by recurrent deterioration, such as asthma7–10and sickle cell disease11–13 tend to have 30-day readmission rates in the 15%-20% range.

These observations lead to the view that the consequences of the present reimbursement policy for readmissions are likely to adversely affect institutions that provide care to the most vulnerable. That is why any assessment of readmission rates should adjust for the child’s illness severity at a minimum, and probably other influences outside the hospital.14

A small number of patients account for a disproportionately large number of admissions.11,13,15 This observation supports the inference that much of the readmission rate might reflect the severity of the underlying illness, although it also supports the inference that some children are at especially high risk of readmission because of lack of resources or noncompliance.

Studies of adults16–21 and children7,9,22–27 have identified public insurance, African American race, reduced social network indicators, living alone, neighborhood conditions (including high measures of poverty), a high number of diagnoses, disease severity, depression, polypharmacy, and weekend discharge as factors leading to greater risk of readmission. Indeed, “safety-net” hospitals serving these patients tend to have 30-day hospital readmission rates 30% above the national average.28

At Boston Children's Hospital, children admitted for intractable seizures, especially those evaluated for surgery, are the neurology service patients most likely to be readmitted within 30 days. This reflects the severity of the underlying seizure disorder and also the consequences of withdrawing antiseizure medications, often in preparation to assess the child’s suitability for surgery.

In the data set provided by 72 members of the National Association of Children's Hospitals and Related Institutions, “diseases of the nervous system and sense organs” was the second most common chronic condition indicator associated with pediatric readmissions within 30 days of discharge.4 The number of dollars spent for readmissions of children with neurologic disorders is likely to be relatively high. In the Kids' Inpatient Database, children with neurologic impairment accounted for approximately one quarter of all children’s bed days and hospital charges.29
We know of no study that identified patient and hospital characteristics associated with the high readmission rate among children admitted for status epilepticus.

Readmission rates for seizures tend to be high, as do readmission rates for other chronic conditions with recurring events, such as sickle cell disease or asthma.4 Such high readmission rates might well be more a consequence of the limitations of outpatient care than of inpatient care. For example, more than 30% of patients who have epilepsy continue to have recurrent seizures despite receiving the accepted standard of care.30

sec.title: Have Efforts to Reduce the Probability of Readmission Been Successful?
sec.p: Despite the focus on readmissions during the past decade, the rates of readmission for congestive heart failure, acute myocardial infarction, and pneumonia among adults have not fallen.18 In addition, efforts to reduce readmission rates have the potential to increase the risk of adverse events and length of stay. For example, some hospitals with high readmission rates for congestive heart failure tend to have lower mortality rates than other institutions.31 Similarly, improvements in care coordination and access to follow-up care have sometimes been followed by increased (yes, increased) rates of readmission.32 The reasons for these unexpected findings remain unclear.

sec.title: What Can Be Done to Reduce the Probability of Readmission?
sec.p: Attempts to reduce readmission rates in general appear to reduce hospital admissions more than readmissions, thereby leaving the actual ratio of admissions to readmissions unchanged while overall hospitalization numbers decline.33 Some readmissions probably can be prevented.17 What proportion, though, remains to be identified.34 In the meantime, we should do what seems likely to be beneficial.

Several programs employ a nurse discharge advocate and/or a personal health coach/coordinator to identify the challenges patients face at home, arrange follow-up appointments, confirm medication reconciliation, and educate patients about what they need to know to care for themselves well. Others have a clinical pharmacist call patients 2 to 4 days after discharge to reinforce the discharge plan and review medications.17 Institutions with the highest outpatient follow-up within 7 days after discharge from a heart failure hospitalization tend to have lower rates of readmission within 30 days than institutions that do not follow such patients so closely.35 For guidance, we recommend Table 2 of “The ReEngineered Discharge (RED) Program.”36

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: We do not know what proportion of readmissions at 30 days (or 60, 90, or 120 days) after discharge can be viewed by most auditors as (possibly or probably) preventable. In light of the evidence that the readmission rate of children to Boston Children's Hospital is influenced by factors that have little to do with adherence to clinical practice guidelines, we expect the proportion to be low. If we knew how low, perhaps authorities might change their minds about using a readmission rate as a quality indicator. In the meantime, while awaiting clarification of how the Affordable Care Act will penalize our institutions for early readmissions, we should do what seems likely to be beneficial.

fn.p: This manuscript was prepared at Boston Children’s Hospital. None of the material in this manuscript was presented at any meeting. No one except the authors contributed to this manuscript.

fn.label: Author Contributions
fn.p: AL prepared the first draft. EA, SA, TL, JM, and SMN offered helpful comments, sometimes adding relevant material and deleting less than relevant material iteratively to the multiple drafts.
